• Men's Grooming

We independently evaluate all recommended products and services. Any products or services put forward appear in no particular order. if you click on links we provide, we may receive compensation.

As I get older, I’m getting the sense that most guys gravitate towards the same four or five fragrances. Nothing wrong with using the greats, but why not shake things up a little bit? For example, you could try out the best Ed Hardy colognes – if you haven’t already.

The way Ed Hardy hooks you in is pretty interesting. Love them or hate them, once you see those colorful, morbid bottle designs, it’s hard to look away. Then you take a whiff, and you start to understand how this dark horse of a brand became an all-time classic.

I can totally see why teenagers love this cologne, but there’s something adult and sultry about it, too. Imagine grandma’s fruit garden mixed with grandpa’s tool shed – the end result is a shockingly manly smelling cologne that keeps you coming back for more.

Interested yet? Let’s have a look at the best Ed Hardy colognes out there.

Key Takeaways

After searching the internet high and low and reading more reviews than I can count, I’ve made my decision. Overall, Ed Hardy Hearts & Daggers Cologne is our favorite pick among the best Ed Hardy colognes. The smell is extremely unique without being outlandish, it’s pleasant without being too much, and it’s a favorite among the ladies, too. All that at a super-fair price.

If you’re after something softer, then Ed Hardy Villain is another of the best Ed Hardy colognes. What makes it so incredible is the seamless transition from watermelon to sage to lavender – not to mention it lasts a fairly long time.


In This Article

  1. Our Picks
  2. Buying Considerations
  3. How We Chose
  4. Why Trust Us?
  5. Final Verdict
  6. FAQs

Best Overall: Ed Hardy Hearts & Daggers Cologne

Why it’s great: To understand why I love this Ed Hardy men’s cologne so much, I refer you to the notes section. It’s not every day that you see a blend of martini, rosemary, suede, and sandalwood, but it works incredibly well.

Plus, 3.4 ounces is pretty generous for how little you’re paying for this. This is one of the best Ed Hardy colognes. Overall, the scent is light and doesn’t overstay its welcome, making this the ultimate casual perfume.

Who is this for? This is one of those colognes that I could recommend to young and middle-aged guys alike. It also makes for a cool gift, since it’s almost guaranteed that the  recipient hasn’t tried anything similar to this. It might get a few ladies to turn their heads, too.

Flaws but not deal-breakers: Don’t let the packaging fool you; this is not an in-your-face, “smell-it-from-a-mile-away” kind of perfume. For my taste, I’d hardly call that a flaw – just a warning to guys who prefer stronger scents.

Top Notes: Martini, pear, basil | Middle Notes: Pepper, papaya, rosemary | Base Notes: Suede, patchouli, sandalwood | Type: Eau de Toilette

Best Budget: Ed Hardy Tiger Ink Body Mist

Why it’s great: Tiger Ink is one of the ultimate budget fragrances, but man, is it good. It puts a twist in the citrusy Ed Hardy formula by throwing mint into the mix. This stuff lasts quite a while, and it gets absorbed by your clothes pretty quickly. Great if you’re after that slightly tangy, spicy scent.

Who is this for? I’d say this is the most unisex of all the picks on this list. If you catch yourself liking traditionally feminine fragrances, chances are you’ll get a real kick out of Tiger Ink. Liking mint and musk is also a huge plus.

Flaws but not deal-breakers: This is one of the best Ed Hardy colognes. Although it’s not overpowering or anything, it does take a little while for the smell to go away. It can be a problem if you don’t like lounging around in your PJs smelling like perfume… or it would be a problem, if it didn’t smell so great.

Top Notes: Mandarin orange, bergamot, sage | Middle Notes: Mint | Base Notes: Amber, musk | Type: Eau de Parfum

Best Luxury: Ed Hardy Born Wild

Why it’s great: If you’re wondering what justifies the price tag on this one, it’s all the female attention you’ll be getting. The combo of apple and citrus is divine, but once the neroli and sandalwood kick in, you start to get the sense you might have even underpaid. For what it’s worth, it’s also my personal favorite Ed Hardy bottle design.

Who is this for? I think any guy who likes fruity perfumes would dig this product. The gentler notes don’t overstay their welcome, so this might be a perfect gateway into the world of Ed Hardy cologne.

Flaws but not deal-breakers: When you consider the price, I do wish it lasted a bit longer. Even still, the smell is so interesting that I think it’s more than worth it.

Top Notes: Cardamom, apple, orange, ambrette | Middle Notes: Pink pepper, jasmine, neroli | Base Notes: Sandalwood | Type: Eau de Toilette

Best on Amazon: Ed Hardy Villain

Why it’s great: In case you haven’t caught on yet, the best Ed Hardy colognes are all a bit experimental with the scents. This beautiful specimen is the softest on this list, combining floral and aquatic notes with hints of watermelon. Still, there’s enough sage and basil to man-ify things up, and the duration is quite impressive, too.

Who is this for? I like to surprise people with rich-smelling perfumes, and if that’s your thing, too, then look no further. Feeling the notes shifting over the first hour or two of wearing the Villain is a delight for the sensitive nose.

Flaws but not deal-breakers: Even by Ed Hardy standards, this perfume smells quite citrusy and flowery. It’s still well into man territory if you ask me, but it’s something to consider if you’re thinking of buying it.
